question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: This class was very stimulating because the material was so new and different from any math class I've done before. All of the concepts build on each other which forces you to really engage with every lecture and make sure you stay on top of things. The class was very challenging - probably one of the most difficult I've taken - but now that I am almost done with it I can see how much I have learned and improved since August.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: This class was stimulating purely because Bayesian statistics as a concept is interesting.Nothing about the way this class was taught was stimulating at all. Lectures were dry and unfocussed to the point where I didn't even bother paying attention sometimes because I knew the professor was teaching us an overly simplified version of what we were expected to know. The homework also bordered on torture because I would spend maybe 1 hour on Bayesian statistic and then another 9+ hours doing algebra. I understand that algebra is an important part of statistics but sometimes the homework problems felt like they were missing the forest for the trees. Bayesian statistics is the forest and algebra is the trees.I would also say almost no concepts in the class struck the boundary well between applied and theoretical. I personally felt like I didn't have the theoretical justification for the applied problems we did (often on the homework or toy examples in class) and I didn't understand how some of the more theoretical concepts (metropolis Hastings, gibbs sampling, etc) were actually applicable.Overall, I would recommend that the statistics department reorganize its major structure so that everyone comes into stat 360 with a really strong core in probability theory and in R coding so that the class can spend less time reteaching things (poorly for that matter) and spend more time building these new concepts.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I would advise a student taking this in the future to set time aside every week to study. It is easy to get caught up in working on the problem sets because they take lots of time, but it is also equally important to stay on top of the material. Start the problem sets early and work on a little at a time!!! Also, the textbook is helpful if there's a concept where the explanation from lecture doesn't quite stick with you, or if you want a more detailed explanation. My last thing would be to persevere! The material is really tough and you'll probably do poorly on a homework or exam at some point, but it's all part of the process of learning new things. If you dedicate enough time, things will start to make more sense.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text:
Do not take this course with Dr. Fisher. He may be a nice human being but he is not a good professor for this class. He is is so set in his ways that he refuses to give students the tools they need to learn. I know from my own experiences as well as talking to peers in the class that the TAs are saving our butts in this class because they filter the things that Dr. Fisher says into what is actually useful.
We had one guest lecture from Dr. Hoff when Dr. Fisher took a day off for paternity leave and it was amazing how much clearer everything was. 
Stat 360 could be an incredibly useful and interesting class if it was just better motivated. I was deciding between majoring and statistics and math but this class made me decide on the math major.So far, this is the only class at Duke where I consistently left lectures, office hours, or time spend working on the homework angry. Not frustrated or discouraged, but angry because it felt like I was being asked to something outside of my capabilities and then when I went to get help on it (and I went to 2-3 office hours sessions a week) the professor just wouldn't be willing to help me. I am fine with struggling in school, but faculties job is to help their students when they're struggling and I never felt like Dr. Fisher actually took time to listen to what his students needed or make necessary changes to his teaching style and office hours structure to meet students where they are.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Unfortunately, I cannot recommend enough that students avoid this class unless it is explicitly required for their major. In fact, at many points in the semester, I was so stressed by this course that I considered changing my major just so I could drop the class. The two saving graces that kept me in the course were 1) I’d have taken a minor in statistics, and this class is required by the minor as well, and 2) I couldn’t graduate on time with a major change this late in my college career. If this course is required for a student, I’d take it alongside only the easiest possible courses, and even then, inform your friends and family that you won’t be available until the semester closes. I am an alternative student in that I am a student veteran with a wife and home, and when family health problems made me a full-time caretaker of my elderly father, I had to stop going to one of my courses lectures entirely to make time to do the problem sets for this course. Simply put, this course will dominate the life of a student taking it, at likely impact their performance in their other courses as well. It should be avoided, even in the face of serious curiosity for the subject, unless explicitly required. I’d advise buying the textbook and working through it at your own pace over a summer for the curious. I’ll probably do the same this summer, so I can do some real learning without the fire hose of homework and exam pressure.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I developed a better understanding of Bayesian statistics (priors/posteriors), learned how to program and use Markov Chain Monto Carlo sampling methods like Metropolis algorithms and Gibbs samplers, as well as the applications of multivariate distributions such as the multivariate normal and the inverse-Wishart distributions.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to improve existing methods of prediction like model building through bayesian approaches of model averaging and ridge regression equivalents. Additionally, I learned how to do the theory that underlies Bayesian statistics like how to derive full conditionals and do some of the hard algebra that underlies the subject. Furthermore, I developed the ability to to do important MCMC methods like Metropolis, Metropolis Hastings, and Gibbs Sampling. This class changed how I viewed statistics. I see statistics as less of a skill or random technical proceedings but as more of a science with significant underlying logic.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1. Constructing priors and obtaining posterior distributions for Bayesian inference. 
2. Writing Monte Carlo samplers to empirically obtain posterior distributions.
3. The differences between Bayesian and frequentist inference and the advantages of one over the other.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Dr. Fisher made the class a very open place for learning. By allowing the classroom to be a place to ask questions, he ensured students could ask questions. He was always a kind human being that made sure students could say they didn't understand what was going on. I think the homeworks were challenging, but they forced me to understand some of the procedures necessary for this class like deriving full conditionals and practicing MCMC code.  The recorded lectures were extremely helpful. Sometimes it takes a few times to hear something and get it but having the opportunity to review the content presented in class is very useful. In addition, I found labs helpful because they presented students with another instructor who was able to explain ideas in a different way and provided practice with some of the more abstract ideas in class. Just like being able to review materials was helpful, hearing two different people (1. prof, 2. lab instructor) talk about the same thing helped students adopt the concept. In the future, I'd keep the labs because I found them helpful. Dr. Fisher was never afraid to pause in class to answer a student's question, even if it meant diverging from the original plan. I really appreciate this. As someone with different neurology than most people, I found it was easier to focus because I knew I could ask questions at any point and he would do his best to answer them.  Another thing I enjoyed was the fact that he tried to incorporate active learning nn the class so students could collaborate with one another and try to ask questions about ideas before information was presented to us. This set us up to think critically about some of the class ideas.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I found the topics highly engaging, and I could tell that Professor Fisher put a lot of thought into how each topic was presented. I really enjoyed the homework sets too. Although they were very challenging, they made me think deeply about the topics we learned in class and provided me with really good practice. I liked that homework problems and class examples often integrated real-world applications, such as the water on Mars class. I like that lab sections were usually an extension of lecture topics, so lab gave me a chance to hear about topics again from a different perspective. Most of all, I appreciate how accessible Professor Fisher and the TAs were. Bayesian is an inherently challenging course, so it makes a huge difference when I can always find help when I need.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I can't stress enough how much I appreciated Professor Reeves's beginning of class summaries, intuitive explanations, and general organization and preparedness. Professor Reeves did an excellent job of motivating/contextualizing new topics, easing us into lectures with reviews of the previous lecture's content, and providing intuitive explanations for concepts that could easily become very heavy in math and notation. I think one of the most important parts of a good teacher's job is providing intuition and connecting the dots between different concepts. It's somewhat easier to develop a basic understanding of concepts by reading a textbook, but something that a textbook can't as fluidly provide is intuition and context. Professor Reeves was so good about pausing and breaking down theorems or new ideas in simple terms. Personally, I find it immensely beneficial to my understanding to hear concepts reduced to simple, even if a bit reductionist terms, before grappling with the full rigorous mathematical presentation of an idea.I also appreciate how organized Professor Reeves was. Homework was always posted on or before the date promised, giving me ample time to work on the assignment before the due date. Lecture notes were also clear, organized, and posted well ahead of the lecture date, allowing me to prepare for lectures and providing a great resource for me to refer to. These lecture notes clearly took time to prepare, so I really appreciate all the time that Professor Reeves dedicated to preparing lecture notes for us. The course followed the posted schedule, and any changes were announced in advance. Homework and exams are also highly representative of the content and examples covered in class.I also really enjoyed the LDOC lecture, where Professor Reeves introduced us to some applications and research topics related to what we learned in class. Overall, Professor Reeves did a fantastic job of presenting a well-organized, intelligent, thoughtful, and reasonable class. I think he really nailed the key points of what a good professor can provide that a textbook cannot. This approach also demonstrated the professor's ability to empathize with students, recognizing where content could be difficult to grasp for the first time and even acknowledging when a quick five minute break could lead to a more productive class.

This has been one of my favorite courses at Duke and definitely my favorite math class at Duke! I think this is the way that math classes should be structured and taught. TA Athena Ru was extremely helpful and smart as well.

Although I understand this was a 'theory' course, what use is all this theory without any practical, real world investigation to how many of these concepts -- MLE, CIs, sufficiency, minimizing risk -- are actually useful in practice. Class time was primarily devoted to long and tedious calculus proofs (homeworks too) rather than problems with real, observable data and practical aspirations. I think class time should be structured around problems in which the outcomes actually means something i.e we reveal some insight that's interesting.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: The amount of time you spend on homework (10+ hours a week) is very annoying because the whole class (70% of final grade) is based on two exams. Therefore, I felt as though my grade in the class wasn’t representative of how hard I tried (I tried very very hard) or the extent of what I learned, but instead on how well I took exams, which, by the way, were multiple choice, which made it very difficult to get a good grade if you made a small mistake but clearly understood a concept well. Would not recommend course unless absolutely necessary. Course was demoralizing and made me drop my stats major, which I was nearly completely done with.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I would not recommend. While it was helpful to return to many of the statistical concepts I've spent my time in stats working through, I found the entirety of this course wholly impractical. Much of our work appeared to be: do long and tedious proofs for the sake of doing these long and tedious proofs. While I think there's a time and a place for working through long equations and derivations, there was much room for practical improvement. I would have loved to see how this statistical tool bag can help me actually do things in practice.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Through this course, I think the biggest skill I learned was how to draw valuable insights from data and tell a story using that data in a compelling way that non-statisticians could understand. I think that working on the case studies helped me learn how to tell a cohesive "story" using that data that we were given. I also learned about many different statistical modeling approaches that I refreshed on from previous classes or new ones that I was able to implement during our case studies.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:

I learned how live, laugh, and love.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This is the first time that I felt that I have actually been able to use everything I have learned over the past few years., and it helped build an immense amount of confidence in my statistical ability. question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I felt like I learned a lot about how to approach problems. Previously, most problems were packaged very nicely. Additionally, a lot of this course was "unlearning" what we learned previously (or at least adding more warning and caution signs to what we previously learned), so that was helpful to learn. (For example, EDA and selection bias). The last specific thing would probably be writing a full-fleshed "research paper."

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Yue is the absolute best! He makes sure to provide incredibly interesting examples in class and for the case studies. His involvement and excitement about the class beyond facilitated my learning. I liked the two case study breakdown and especially the ability to revise our work (that was what I was able to learn the most from). I also really like the randomized groups. It gave the chance to work with stats majors that had taken different courses or timing of courses than I had so that I was able to learn from their experience as well.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I think that having the two submissions – an intial submission and a final submission – and getting targeted feedback to be able to work on it in between was helpful in facilitating my learning and being able to learn in real time. I also enjoyed having a mini case study at the start of the semester to get used to working on before the start of our group projects. In addition, I also enjoyed being able to stick with my group for the second case study as we had already figured out our work styles.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Doctor Banks is an excellent professor. He's patient, always willing to answer questions in class, and even encourages us to ask more during lectures. He's highly knowledgeable and approachable. Not only does he provide deeper insights into the lessons, but he's also eager to share his industry and academic expertise. His experience and expertise make his advice incredibly valuable. I truly enjoy my time in his class and find interacting with him to be a rewarding experience. He genuinely cares about his students and their success.Regarding the course components for future years, I believe keeping the lecture slides is beneficial. They offer a broad overview of various techniques and make it easy to compare and understand their pros and cons. While most lecture slides are well-written and clear (if you read them carefully), I find the second half of the slides more comprehensible and relatable. Dr. Banks has also employed various methods to test and support our understanding, including different types of homework. Personally, I particularly enjoy project-type assignments like the Latent Dirichlet Allocation project. They feel like mini-projects where I can explore algorithms and add my unique findings, aligning closely with what we've learned in class.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text:
The material itself has a lot of potential, and I like the concept of this class being less theoretical. I wish that in the future, this class can get changed again so that it covers maybe fewer things, but in a bit more depth. Or, fully lean into it being more practical and actually make it a high level overview kind of course, take out ALL the theory, and focus on our conceptual understanding, ability to explain the topics coherently to a less technical audience, and ability to put the models covered in class into practice. I had a classmate who mentioned an interesting idea, making the final project into a mock interview sort of thing. While it would be a lot harder, I think that's a really interesting direction to take the class, and keeps with the spirit of the changes made to it already. I know as an MSS student that our proseminar class kind of covered interview prep / career stuff, but just an idea haha.
If they really want to cater to the students who want to be data scientists, I think they should show us all the topics they have for this class, and then ask us what WE want to cover and what would be useful to us to understand, instead of speedrunning literally everything in the book. Also I think it would be easier on the instructor as well, because there were clearly certain areas he didn't understand as well, yet still tried to give lectures on. 
Also, the labs were basically just the TAs talking through an already filled out R Markdown file, so it was mostly just for participation, which I appreciated but also made it really easy to tune out and disengage from. I would've enjoyed it more if those labs felt a bit more interactive, and we got to do some hands on stuff related to what was covered in class.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: This is by far my best class at Duke. Professor Tokdar explains the concepts really well. I remember having a lot of 'wow' moments when learning about Fisher/Neyman approaches, MLE, optimal tests, shrinkage, etc. He encourages us to ask questions in class, which helps us understand the concepts better. He is also extremely helpful during office hours, where he walks us through the concepts, explains how to solve challenging parts of the homework, and sometimes discusses other research-related topics. The homework is a nice addition to the lectures, as it helped me work out specific details of what we learned in class. Apart from his ability to deliver the lectures, he struck me as a very caring professor because of the little details, such as remembering all of our names, asking us on the first day of class what we wanted to learn and how he could help us study better, encouraging discussion in class, combining writing and slides and moving deadlines when necessary. Additionally, the TAs were also very helpful during office hours. Overall, I'm grateful to study under the guidance of an amazing professor like him.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: In this course, I've achieved the following:I've built a solid foundation in Bayesian Statistics, encompassing crucial concepts such as constructing priors and posteriors, understanding conjugate families, and deriving components for algorithms like Monte Carlo and MCMC. Additionally, I've delved into topics such as hierarchical modeling.The course's comprehensive approach, which includes class lectures, labs, office hours, and substantial homework assignments, has significantly enhanced my coding and visualization skills related to both concepts and algorithms. This has not only deepened my understanding but also improved my coding proficiency.Through diligent reading of the textbook in conjunction with lecture slides, I've honed my comprehension skills. Moreover, I've developed the ability to generalize problems from simpler steps. For instance, I've learned to extend formulas from univariate to multivariate models and simplify formulas with fewer assumptions.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Professor Li Ma is exceptionally organized, and his course materials are meticulously structured for easy comprehension. For instance, his class lectures seamlessly connect and complement one another, providing valuable guidance for students, whether they choose to delve into the textbook in detail or not.Moreover, Professor Li Ma is always open to questions in class and excels at explaining complex concepts. He explains the meaning of each term in a formula and provides insight into the effects of altering various components in the prior or the modeling on the posterior. He also discusses how excluding specific assumptions can lead to modifications in the final results.During office hours, he not only endeavors to answer students' questions comprehensively but also willingly discusses various aspects of research and industry. This provides us with valuable insights into current research and professional directions. Beyond his expertise, Professor Li Ma is understanding, personable, and adds humor to the class through appreciated jokes. Additionally, the support from both office hours and teaching assistants is highly commendable.

response_text:

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I developed a much deeper understanding of numerical linear algebra, especially in how least-squares problems, iterative solvers, and matrix factorizations are applied in real-world data analysis.I improved my ability to translate mathematical models into code, particularly using MATLAB and LaTeX in tandem for clear and reproducible numerical experiments.I gained valuable insights into the connection between numerical stability and algorithm design, which helped me build intuition for choosing appropriate numerical methods depending on the problem context.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1. Error analysis and numerical stability: I can now distinguish truncation error from rounding error and use condition numbers to judge an algorithm’s sensitivity.  
2. Core algorithm implementation: I wrote and debugged Python/MATLAB code for Newton’s method, LU factorization, and Runge–Kutta schemes, and can explain their convergence order and cost.  
3.  A numerical way of thinking: I shifted from “exact analytical answers” to “controlled approximations,” selecting methods that balance accuracy and efficiency for a given problem size.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text:

5. Payoff: by the end you’ll judge algorithm stability, write your own solvers, and think like an applied mathematician—skills that transfer directly to data science, ML, and simulation projects.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1. Error analysis and numerical stability: I can now distinguish truncation error from rounding error and use condition numbers to judge an algorithm’s sensitivity.  
2. Core algorithm implementation: I wrote and debugged Python/MATLAB code for Newton’s method, LU factorization, and Runge–Kutta schemes, and can explain their convergence order and cost.  
3. A numerical way of thinking: I shifted from “exact analytical answers” to “controlled approximations,” selecting methods that balance accuracy and efficiency for a given problem size.

I would strongly recommend keeping the dual-component homework format and the encouragement for creative approaches in future years.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I really liked how Dr. Xu focused on the intuitions we should understand/be developing when deriving solutions and identifying properties of timeseries models. He didn't just have a slide that went from one equation to another or go through these derivations rapidly in class. Instead, he made this a slower process and took the time to carefully explain each step of the derivation and check in with students to make sure they were understanding as he proceeded. If students were not understanding, he took the time to find analogies or other connections to make his point more clear. This was especially helpful for me, as I don't have an extensive background in statistics courses.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The instructor overall did poorly in facilitating our learning. While I acknowledge the projects were designed with the ideas of challenging us to go above and beyond and make some contributions to open source that could add to our portfolio, the instructor provided very unclear guidelines and minimal help outside of class for those. For example, we received 0 feedback for project 1 draft submission (which was promised) and received 0 reply for tons of questions on ed during the spring break, during which many of us worked very hard to complete the projects and prepare the presentation. The grading and the judgment on the so called "level of complexity" seemed to be very subjective for me and did not account for the fact that many of us are new to Python and we received almost no feedback and help during the process.Some of the labs are valuable resources, and the TAs are generally helpful on them, but we still completed them and learned the material mostly with the help of ChatGPT. The lectures are generally disorganized and  did not really cover the coding and application aspects in detail, which are pretty detached from what we are doing in the labs. There are also too many lectures used on presentations and guest lectures, and I hardly ever felt this course has a focus on Python programming. The syllabus also kept changing during the semester right until almost the end of the term, which makes it very hard for us to know what to expect and plan accordingly.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The structured course and lab schedule provided through a Google Sheet significantly facilitated my learning by offering clear visibility on deadlines and expectations. This organizational tool was crucial in managing my time efficiently and reducing stress. Additionally, the instructors’ approach to delivering clear explanations and detailed feedback on each project and course content was exceptionally beneficial. It allowed for a deeper understanding of complex topics and helped improve my skills through constructive criticism. For future iterations of this course, I would strongly recommend retaining these elements. Incorporating more interactive components, such as peer reviews and group projects, could further enhance engagement and practical learning. Additionally, introducing digital tools for real-time feedback during lectures could provide immediate clarifications, making the learning process even more effective and interactive.

Ideally i'd have more of those (but at a different time). Also, I liked how the projects were customizable to our interests and could be used in our portfolios.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I do think that this course could have been done better overall, but then again, my level of engagement with the course was not best. As for the learning environment, I cannot say that it was "bad", but there was definitely a feeling that the course was just tailored towards students whose forte is ML to begin with (these students are not learning much) and that the rest of us were a little bit left behind. I think that given the number of students (relatively small number) who effectively knew most of the things in class that were covered, the instructors could have done a better job of slowing down and making sure that the rest of us also get something from each lecture. I also think that, overall, the disconnect between homework assignments and what was covered in lectures was quite high, which is never easy for students.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: In this course, I gained a solid foundation in interpretable machine learning techniques, such as sparse decision trees, generalized additive models, and interpretable neural networks, which taught me the importance of balancing accuracy with explainability. I also developed a deeper understanding of fundamental machine learning algorithms, including random forests, SVMs, and neural networks, while exploring theoretical concepts through statistical learning theory. Additionally, I improved my practical skills by mastering evaluation techniques like ROC curves, cross-validation, and nested cross-validation, which are essential for assessing the performance of machine learning models effectively.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
I gained knowledge of the fundamental theories and algorithms of machine learning, along with related concepts such as cross-validation and optimization methods. Three specific aspects I found particularly useful are:
1. The foundational machine learning models, such as logistic regression, decision trees, and random forests.
2. Basic statistical concepts for data preprocessing, like normalization.
3. Key principles of neural networks, including convolutional networks and transformers.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text:
For the course, the difficulty is quite high. Before choosing the class, it's a good idea to review the publicly available course materials. If the difficulty seems too high, you can consider choosing another course. It's important to prepare in advance; otherwise, it might be hard to follow the class. I consider that the most important aspect of the course is understanding the logic behind various machine learning algorithms. If you get stuck with mathematical derivations, don't worry—feel free to ask the TA for help.
As for the assignments, they are challenging, so it's best to start each one early. However, the grading is quite fair. If you encounter any problems, you can always consult the TA, as they are very helpful. The project offers a lot of flexibility and is quite interesting. It allows you to practice the entire machine learning and data analysis workflow, which is a great opportunity to develop those skills.
Additionally, this course focuses a lot on traditional algorithms. If you’re expecting to learn about deep learning applications like computer vision or natural language processing, then this might not be the course you're looking for.

As for the learning environment, I cannot say that it was "bad", but there was definitely a feeling that the course was just tailored towards students whose forte is ML to begin with (these students are not learning much) and that the rest of us were a little bit left behind. I think that given the number of students (relatively small number) who effectively knew most of the things in class that were covered, the instructors could have done a better job of slowing down and making sure that the rest of us also get something from each lecture. I also think that, overall, the disconnect between homework assignments and what was covered in lectures was quite high, which is never easy for students.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
I gained knowledge of the fundamental theories and algorithms of machine learning, along with related concepts such as cross-validation and optimization methods. Three specific aspects I found particularly useful are:
1. The foundational machine learning models, such as logistic regression, decision trees, and random forests.
2. Basic statistical concepts for data preprocessing, like normalization.
3. Key principles of neural networks, including convolutional networks and transformers.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about a lot of the theory behind machine learning algorithms like AdaBoost and SVMs, like what makes them work. Getting to the see the professor talk through the code of GOSDT (optimal decision tree algorithm she worked on) was really cool. Also getting to implement these myself, like on the first homework assignment where I had to write KNN from scratch and the last one where we did k-means clustering for images.

Lastly, the lectures more or less nailed each topic and helped prepare me for interviews + class deliverables.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The instructor was super friendly and passionate and knowledgeable about machine learning. I was on the fence about taking this class at first, but her presence really sold the class to me and I'm glad I got to take it with her. I liked the format of the class relying on homework and final project, I think it suits the content.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Methods used: singing, handwriting notes, relevant game demonstrations, videos (for visualizations), and slide show presentation. I would keep all of these methods (they are great) with a minor tweak on the slide shows. I specifically recall one class where we learned about transforms, defusion, and GCN in one slide deck presentation (was too much).

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: -in this course, you don’t learn much from lectures but rather office hours, how much you learn depends on how engaged you are with the HWs. There are no exams, just 4 month-long HWs, and a final Kaggle Competition/Final Project. The homework’s consist of theory questions and coding questions. I learned about the basics of Scikit-learn, PyTorch, to use KNN, bagging, Boosting, and various models in coding problems. I learned about variance, regularizations, a lot of proofs involving probability in the theory questions. Some degree of self-learning and visiting office hours is required to tackle these problems.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: In this course, I gained a solid foundation in interpretable machine learning techniques, such as sparse decision trees, generalized additive models, and interpretable neural networks, which taught me the importance of balancing accuracy with explainability. I also developed a deeper understanding of fundamental machine learning algorithms, including random forests, SVMs, and neural networks, while exploring theoretical concepts through statistical learning theory. Additionally, I improved my practical skills by mastering evaluation techniques like ROC curves, cross-validation, and nested cross-validation, which are essential for assessing the performance of machine learning models effectively.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This course is both challenging and rewarding, offering a comprehensive overview of machine learning techniques and concepts. It is ideal for students with a strong foundation in linear algebra, probability, and programming who are ready to put in the effort to engage with a fast-paced curriculum. The recorded lectures and detailed notes are excellent resources for independent learning, and the instructors genuinely care about student success. However, be prepared to work independently on homework assignments, start them early, and dedicate sufficient time to understand the material. If you are up for the challenge, this course will significantly deepen your understanding of machine learning and provide valuable skills for academic or professional growth.

response_text: I had not actually taken an introductory Bayesian course when I registered for this course, but the ramp up to more complex models taught in this course was a welcoming introduction to this type of statistical thinking that transferred well in STA602L, which I took at the same time. In this course, you definitely get a handle on Stan coding, and I like how the professor doesn't overload you with mathematical notation but a sufficient amount that allows you to understand the concepts and be able to code it up. Since it is a data science course within healthcare applications, it's interesting to see how these methods are applied and think about when such models are necessary for the problem you are facing, whether it be for interpretability or ability to capture the data well.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: The course is a great review of various methods of classical inference for discrete data. as well as key concepts in statistical inference including exponential families. The course lecture notes and the textbooks have become immensely valuable reference for potential future usage.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: GLM modeling, Model comparison with deviance, Analysis of contingency tables

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
Traditional large-sample-based methods.
Variations of logit models and Poisson models.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: In this course, I learned how to generalize the linear models framework to accommodate discrete responses from exponential families and analyze these data in a principled manner, like through analysis of deviance. I also learned how to analyze discrete data with from two- and three-way contingency tables using proportional odds models. I also learned how to implement Polya-Gamma data augmentation.

response_text: Very good of the class size and in-class interactions with the questions raised by students.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Li Ma's lectures were very well delivered, and his slides are well organized, so it is fairly easy to go back and re-read them. The problem sets, though few, were also properly suited to have us test our understanding of the material with a combination of simulations and real-world data analysis. I also appreciated the paper presentation and final project innovations, as it helped me branch out in my interests and learn methods I had either never heard of before or had never tried to implement. Those are definitely worth keeping around in future iterations of the course.
